title: My mom kissed LO in front of me and denied it & physically touches him too much (imo). How serious is this?
opening_message: "I'm really struggling to reconcile my mom's otherwise loving behavior towards my baby with some recent incidents that have made me uncomfortable and concerned."

all: I have bad memories of my mom forcing me to kiss her and it makes me feel gross because I didn't have a choice when I was little, and now it's affecting my behavior as a parent.
My mom's actions towards me as a child (tickling, biting) were not just harmless fun, but actually traumatizing for me.
As a parent myself, I'm noticing similar concerning behaviors from my mom with my own baby (kissing, poking, tickling), and it's making me uncomfortable.
When I addressed these issues with my mom, she denied or minimized them, which makes me feel frustrated and worried about my child's safety.
I value consent and believe babies can communicate their boundaries through smiles and reactions, so I ask for permission before kissing my son.
My mom's comments about biting my baby's legs and telling him to leave her alone with him are concerning and have made me hesitant to leave them together unsupervised.
I'm questioning whether I should continue to trust my mom as a babysitter given these incidents, despite her being otherwise amazing with my child.
The fact that this behavior is recent (within the last week) and seems to be escalating has me worried about what might happen if I don't set boundaries.
As a parent, it's hard for me not to take these incidents seriously, even if others might think I'm being overly cautious or dramatic.
I want my baby to feel safe and respected in his interactions with others, including family members like my mom, and I'm willing to have tough conversations to ensure that happens.

turns.content: "I'm really struggling to reconcile my mom's otherwise loving behavior towards my baby with some recent incidents that have made me uncomfortable and concerned."

I can totally understand why you're feeling uneasy about this, mama! It's natural to want to trust and rely on your mom for support. Can you tell me more about what happened in those recent incidents that left you feeling concerned? What specifically made you feel uncomfortable?

"I know it sounds weird, but seeing those things happen to my mom has really made me realize that I don't want her doing that to my own kid. It's like, I get that she means well, but it just feels... off to me. And now I'm worried about what habits she might be passing down or what kind of influence she could have on my little one."

I hear you, mama! It makes sense that seeing those behaviors would make you want to protect your own child from similar experiences. It's like, you're taking a step back and thinking about the kind of mom you want to be and the kind of relationships you want your kid to have. What do you think is the biggest difference between what you saw happening with your mom and how you want to handle things with your own child?

"I guess what really stands out to me is how different it feels to prioritize consent with my own child, even at a young age. Seeing my mom's behavior as a kid, I never felt like I had any agency or control over our interactions. But now, asking my son for permission before kissing him or giving hugs feels like a fundamental shift in how I approach our relationship. It's like, I'm actually considering his boundaries and feelings, rather than just assuming he wants attention or affection."

That's such an important realization, mama! It takes courage to acknowledge the ways you want to be different from your own experiences. Prioritizing consent with your child is a powerful way to build trust and respect in your relationship. What do you think would happen if you were to have an open conversation with your mom about these differences and why they're important to you?

I'm not sure, but I feel like having that conversation with my mom would be really scary. I don't want to come across as accusatory or critical, but at the same time, I need to express how her behavior is affecting me and my relationship with my child. It's hard for me to think about having a calm and respectful conversation when all I can hear is her dismissive tone saying "oh, she'll be fine" and "stop being so sensitive".

I totally get it, mama! It sounds like you're worried about how your mom might respond, which is understandable. Having tough conversations with loved ones can be really challenging. Have you thought about what would make you feel more prepared or empowered to have that conversation? Maybe there's something specific you could do to help you feel more confident and calm before talking to your mom?

"I guess what's really bothering me is that I've always thought of my mom as this reliable and trustworthy person, but now I'm second-guessing everything. I feel like if I don't confront these issues, it might blow up in a bigger way later on... and the thought of not being able to trust her with my kid's safety is just really scary."

I can sense the weight of that concern, mama! It sounds like you're feeling a deep sense of unease about your mom's reliability and trustworthiness. That must be really distressing for you. What do you think would happen if you were to talk to your mom about these concerns in a non-accusatory way? Would it help to frame the conversation around your own feelings and needs, rather than attacking or criticizing her?

I'm really scared that if I don't address this, it's going to get out of control and affect my kids. The thought of having to deal with the fallout from her unpredictable behavior is keeping me up at night. If I could just have a calm conversation with her about how her actions are impacting me and my family, maybe we could find some kind of solution together?

I hear you, mama! It sounds like you're feeling overwhelmed by the possibility of things escalating and affecting your kids. You're hoping to find a way to address the issue before it's too late. What do you think would be the most important thing for you to say or express in that conversation with your mom?

"Honestly, I'm really struggling with this because every time I've tried to talk to my mom about her behavior, she just dismisses it or tells me I'm being paranoid. It feels like no matter what I say, nothing will ever change and that's scaring me because I don't want my kids to get hurt. I feel like I'm stuck between trying to protect them and not wanting to have another argument with her."

I can sense the frustration and helplessness you're feeling, mama! It sounds like you've tried talking to your mom before, but it didn't lead to any positive changes. You're worried that if you don't do something different this time, nothing will change and your kids might get hurt. What would make you feel more confident or prepared for a conversation with your mom this time around?

"Honestly, I'm scared that if I don't do something different this time, I'll just end up feeling like I did when I was a kid - powerless and hurt. The thought of being in a situation where my mom might dismiss or minimize my concerns all over again is terrifying to me. I think what would make me feel more confident is having a clear plan for how I can protect myself and my kids from her potential reactions."

I hear the deep-seated fear, mama! It sounds like you're scared of reliving past experiences and feeling powerless again. You want to feel prepared and in control this time around. Having a clear plan for how to protect yourself and your kids is crucial. What's one small step you could take today or tomorrow to start building that plan?

"I know it sounds crazy, but what if something happens again? What if I'm not enough to keep my kids safe? I feel like I'm constantly wondering 'what ifs' and it's exhausting. If I can just have a plan in place, maybe that'll give me some sense of control and peace."
